Key Match Events: Tyler O’Neill ended the game with one swing, slugging a three-run homer off Keegan Akin in the 10th inning and sending the ball over the Green Monster and onto Lansdowne Street.
Emmanuel Rivera hit a go-ahead RBI single in the top of the 10th to cap a 2-for-4 performance that also featured a third-inning home run.
Pre-Game Insights: The Orioles (83-64) sit 1 1/2 games behind the first-place Yankees (84-62) in the American League East standings.
Baltimore, which has 15 games remaining, still sits atop the AL Wild Card standings, with a three-game advantage over Kansas City (80-67), the current second Wild Card.
Post-Match Reflections: ‘Definitely frustrating, you know?’ Akin said. ‘We’re at kind of a crucial point right now. Haven’t really been playing our best ball, but I think it’s coming, I do. You’re starting to see a little bit of it. Just got to kind of put it all together at one time, and I think we’ll go from there.’
‘I wish that was my job to tell you, but that's not my job. My job is to go out there and pitch,’ right-hander Dean Kremer said.

Orioles manager Brandon Hyde could have intentionally walked the right-handed-hitting O’Neill to load the bases. But the Sox likely would have then sent Rob Refsnyder to the plate in place of Masataka Yoshida.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Orioles haven’t been playing like a team capable of going on a deep postseason run. They’re 25-26 since the All-Star break, and they’ve lost five of their past seven.

Emmanuel Rivera was nearly an unlikely hero for the O’s. The 28-year-old journeyman infielder hit a go-ahead RBI single in the top of the 10th to cap a 2-for-4 performance that also featured a third-inning home run.
